wordlists.name: SecLists Top 20 (trimmed)
wordlists.description: High-frequency passwords pulled from the SecLists common credentials set.

wordlists.name: SecLists Names (excerpt)
wordlists.description: Common given names useful for username-style candidates.

wordlists.name: UK NCSC Top 10 (2023 excerpt)
wordlists.description: Public stats from the UK National Cyber Security Centre on most common passwords.

commands.label: Raw MD5 single hash
commands.description: Demo of cracking a lone raw MD5 hash using a trimmed SecLists wordlist.
notes: Use trimmed fixtures only; do not point at live systems.
Pair with the "SecLists Top 20" excerpt to keep runtime tiny.

commands.label: Zip archive hash
commands.description: Illustrates format selection for PKZIP hashes backed by a names-based wordlist.
notes: These samples mimic training vault exports.
Names list keeps the keyspace approachable for workshops.

commands.label: SHA1 audit replay
commands.description: Replays a failed run against a SHA1 hash to teach follow-up tactics.
notes: Pairs with the "Wordlist exhausted" interpretation card.
Encourage iterating on rules once the baseline fails.

results.title: Raw-MD5 quick win
results.summary: SecLists excerpt finds an MD5 password immediately.
results.output:
Loaded 1 password hash (Raw-MD5 [MD5 128/128 AVX2 8x1])
Press 'q' or Ctrl-C to abort, almost any other key for status
password (alice)
1g 0:00:00:00 DONE (2024-01-01 00:00) 100.0g/s 0p/s 0c/s 0C/s
Use the "--show" option to display all of the cracked passwords reliably
Session completed.
interpretation: Header confirms the hash format and SIMD backend in use.
Credential pairs print in the `password (username)` format on success.
Tiny runtime reflects the trimmed training wordlist.

results.title: Wordlist exhausted without match
results.summary: SHA1 hash remains after running the NCSC excerpt.
results.output:
Loaded 1 password hash (Raw-SHA1 [SHA1 256/256 AVX2 8x])
Press 'q' or Ctrl-C to abort, almost any other key for status
Session completed.
0 password hashes cracked, 1 left
interpretation: Header still provides format confirmation even on failure.
Footer states how many hashes remain, steering students to new tactics.
